Thought.Thought: This squeak is unbearably loud.

NextNode.Thought: These are the floorboards.It's an old house.

When I lived at home the floorboards also squeaked.But it was quickly lost in the everyday noises.My mother would probably have called out to me from the living room telling me to take off my street shoes.Now there is dead silence here.In the truest sense of the word.

Links.Option: My mother will never scold me again.
Why isn't there anything else to hear?

NextNode.Thought: I guess no one has been here in the last few weeks since Lydia died.She was found dead in the dining room.
Probably because I haven't seen or heard from her in 10 years since I moved out.My mother is as foreign to me as my high school class teacher.

Links.Option: Good this way.That makes it easier.
Why can I accept this idea so easily?

Against the cold Nordic wind and frequent rain.In Northern Germany this is part of the standard equipment.
lastnode

True.I don't spend any money on something like that.

NextNode.Thought: I can't even remember this sight.In my memory, the only bright thing in the room was the television that was always on.I spent most of my time here with my mother.I did homework and watched the television that was always on when my mother was there.

Links.Option: Watching TV together used to be my favorite thing.I couldn't do anything wrong here.
Even when we were together, we just lived next to each other.

Thought.Thought: The path to the hallway

NextNode.Thought: Get back to work?

Links.Option: I'd rather keep looking around here.

Things.Name: shelf
Things.ExamineText: Shelf with art objects

Thought.Thought: On the shelf there is a lamp with a clay body, a wooden box and a framed picture colored in watercolor.

NextNode.Thought: The items are all from the family.They've been on the shelf for as long as I can remember.

My mother made the lamp herself as a young woman.I know from stories that she enjoyed working with clay.She even had a pottery wheel and was quite successful in selling ceramics locally.She proudly said that again and again when she remembered.But that was before my time.She couldn't have been older than twenty.

Links.Option: It's a shame she didn't continue.She then became a saleswoman in the supermarket.That's probably not how she imagined it.

NextNode.Thought: My grandma made them.And her parents built this house here.

Links.Option: My work as a restorer cannot keep up with that.
The box is very beautifully crafted.
The picture was clearly painted by a child, but has a very nice color composition.

NextNode.Thought: That was me.I couldn't have been older than six then.It was before I started school.

Links.Option: One of the rare moments in which my mother was impressed - but that's easier as a small child.

NextNode.Thought: But it was my grandma who had it framed.Back then, this was my grandparents' bedroom.My mother and I lived upstairs.

Links.Option: My whole family was skilled at crafts.

NextNode.Thought: That's probably why I became a restorer.

Links.Option: When I was accepted to the vocational school, that was the only moment my mother was proud of me.I had finally done something right.

Things.Name: sofa
Things.ExamineText: A comfortable sofa

Thought.Thought: A cozy looking sofa made of velvet fabric.The sofa looks significantly less worn than the armchair next to it.

NextNode.Thought: I used to often sit here while my mother watched TV.

Links.Option: Doing homework here didn't necessarily help me in school.It probably took me twice as long and only understood half as much.
Sometimes there were visitors too.And everyone squeezed onto the sofa.Except my mother.
It was very quiet here alone.

NextNode.Thought: I was often here when I felt lonely.When I think about it, I immediately feel sad.

Links.Option: Sometimes loneliness is a beautiful thing.
Lonely because I needed my mother and she wasn't there.
Drop it on like before;Knees to your chest, compressing yourself, becoming nothing.Fall asleep.[lie down]

Things.Name: TV
Things.ExamineText: The old television in GDR style

Thought.Thought: An old television.Probably from the eighties.It's been here for as long as I can remember.

NextNode.Thought: When Lydia wasn't working, she sat here and watched TV.A cup of coffee at lunchtime and a glass of wine in the evening.That was her after-work beer.
As a child, I enjoyed watching TV with her.I was doing homework and kept squinting at the TV.It was a way to spend time with her.As a teenager it rather annoyed me.

Links.Option: Maybe that's why I still like watching trashy court shows on TV.
That's why I don't have a television.

NextNode.Thought: Maybe it was a few glasses on some evenings.I didn't count.

Links.Option: I also like to drink a glass (or two) in the evening.
Maybe she had a drinking problem.But as a child I didn't notice it.Maybe that only came after I moved out.

NextNode.Thought: That's what I associate with her most: working in the supermarket, then she comes home and watches TV.Only the garden comes to mind.That was perhaps even more important to her than the television.

Links.Option: The garden is a better memory than watching TV.
From a distance, it sounds like a very lonely everyday life.

Things.Name: Armchair
Things.ExamineText: A very outdated armchair.

Thought.Thought: A very outdated armchair.The fabric cover is cracked and faded.

NextNode.Thought: This was Lydia's throne.This is where she sat most of the day with the best view of the television.

Links.Option: What is it like to sit there?

NextNode.Thought: I was never allowed to sit there before.Even now I don't dare.It feels wrong.As if I would somehow become my mother.It feels wrong to even think about it.

Links.Option: It's funny that I don't dare.What probably happened in the past when I sat down anyway?I can't remember.
I definitely don't want to be like my mother.I'd rather not risk that.
The armchair looks strange and familiar at the same time.Now even Lydia's throne is mine.

Things.Name: Garden window
Things.ExamineText: Window to the garden

Thought.Thought: The garden blooms beautifully at this time of year.I completely forgot about the beautiful, big tree.

NextNode.Thought: Now that I see the garden I am happy.So many beautiful memories suddenly come to mind!
We used to often do gardening together or I would play in the garden with friends.There were also certain places where I wasn't allowed to play because of the plants.

Links.Option: Lydia used to really get excited when there was gardening to do on the weekend.

NextNode.Thought: And then I immediately felt better.I often longed for the weekend because I knew that would be when my mother would take care of the garden.

Links.Option: I have always enjoyed working with plants.
Maybe I was looking forward to Lydia being in a good mood and digging less in the dirt.
I was looking forward to spending time with Lydia.As far as I remember, we didn't do much together.
A much nicer activity than her other leisure activity: watching television.

NextNode.Thought: It was their house and also their garden when they were still alive.But that was a very long time ago.My mother and I helped my grandmother.I must have been four or five then.But my memories don't go back any further.My mother was often annoyed that my grandmother bossed her around in the garden.I then helped her and her mood quickly improved again.I liked that as a little child.

Links.Option: I no longer had this positive effect on her later.

NextNode.Thought: My mother would never have allowed that.But the plants don't grow that fast.Apparently Lydia hasn't been taking good care of the garden in the last few days either.What was wrong with her?

Links.Option: Maybe she had been exhausted for a while.Bad harbingers.
The tumor may not have been her only problem.
The garden looks unkempt.The plants grow all over the place.
She always took me to the garden when I was feeling bad.[looking out]

NextNode.Thought: True, that's how it was.That often helped.Although I'm not sure if it was really about the garden or more about spending carefree time with Lydia.

Links.Option: When I think about it, Lydia often felt bad first.

NextNode.Thought: She sometimes lay in bed in her room for days.I then made myself breakfast, went to school and then cooked us both lunch.
But I never felt powerless.It was my time to take care of her.

Links.Option: I had done something to cheer her up.

NextNode.Thought: It also had something to do with the garden.I just remember always going into her room after school.

Links.Option: Maybe I'll find something in her room.
She must have been severely depressed during my childhood.

Things.Name: Telephone and address book
Things.ExamineText: Telephone and address book

Thought.Thought: Lydia actually still had a landline phone.

NextNode.Thought: This reminds me of hours of phone calls with my best school friend Hanna.
There are a lot of names here, along with phone numbers and addresses.
No idea who that is.
I remember!Karim was probably my first great love.
We often met after school.And once I was with him.

My mother didn't want me to go there and spend the night with him.Sleep over with a boy?Who knows what kind of ideas they will come up with.That was definitely my mother's fear.I went to see him anyway and told my mother I was with a friend.

But she must have figured it out somehow.When I came back she just ignored me.Not a word spoken to me.When this went on all day, I started crying, but she continued to ignore me.Any blow for my lie would have been less bad.

I could only guess that my lie had been discovered and she was angry with me.I lay in my room for the rest of the weekend and just wished that my mother would notice me again.And at some point I was afraid that I had become invisible.

On Monday morning when I had to go to school, the table was suddenly set and breakfast was served.My mother routinely asked me if I wanted orange juice.I was confused but at the same time so overjoyed to be visible to her again that I didn't question it further.

But back then it was my justified punishment for doing what I wanted.I was so afraid that I would become invisible again that I tried to meet all of my mother's needs and not do anything "wrong" from her point of view.
Now it's too late.She will ignore me forever.

Links.Option: Even now I mostly feel guilt.I regret that I never visited Lydia again.

Commands.ThoughtText: I wish I could work in the garden with my mother again.Then I would feel better.

Links.Option: I was in love and wanted to be with Karim.From today's perspective, the fact that my mother ignored me for days as a reaction seems completely exaggerated.
Maybe she couldn't see me anymore.
I didn't even really know why she ignored me.
How could I forget him so completely?
Let's take a look at the address book next to the phone.[Read]
I don't have to call anyone right now.

Things.Name: Stain on carpet
Things.ExamineText: There is a big stain on the carpet.

Thought.Thought: There is a big stain on the carpet.

NextNode.Thought: The stain makes me sad.He makes me feel ashamed.But why?

Links.Option: Is the stain here because of me?[Investigate]

NextNode.Thought: Now I remember.Here I had a bad argument with my mother.Shortly afterwards I moved out.And now ten years have passed.
I can't think of it anymore.All I remember is my uncontrollable anger.I had to get rid of her.And then I pushed Lydia with all my might.

She had a glass of cherry juice in her hand.Suddenly the memory is so clear.When I shed her she spilled all the cherry juice on the carpet.She slammed into the back wall of the room.She screamed "Get out!"It echoes in my ears again.She screamed it with all her heart.

I didn't even know what was happening to me.I couldn't help but do what my mother said.I moved out.My mother stopped speaking to me.I saw no way to reconcile with her.Years later I tried to reach her without success.I was already in Hamburg.Then I gave up.The shame was too great.All that remained from the memory was the vague idea of an argument and the feeling of guilt and futility.
And that culminated in the ultimate disrespect: physical violence.

Links.Option: My poor mother.I'm just causing trouble.I'm worthless.
In my memory, I only worried my mother.
This is how the stain came about.
It was more than words that we threw at each other.What was it about?

EventThought.Thought: My cell phone rings.That too... [Accept call]

NextNode.Thought: Hello Marla, Frank here.
I know you took some time off.But I just noticed that your work on the statue isn't finished yet.But it has to be ready for return in three weeks.
No!I assumed you would finish the work beforehand.Of course it doesn't work that way.It's clear.
So it wasn't agreed that way.You get two weeks.Afterwards you have to be back here and finish the work.Can you do it in a week?
Marla?
Good.Otherwise you'll have to take some time off afterwards if you still need some time.That's just not how it works.Then we'll see each other in two weeks.OK?

Commands.ThoughtText: I'm just not doing anything right.Why am I like this?I just want to lie down and sleep.

Links.Option: I thought someone would do it for me.We talked about it then, right?

Thought.Thought: The kitchen looks a bit chaotic.

NextNode.Thought: It happened here.

Links.Option: I ate here with my mother as a small child.

NextNode.Thought: It was the only part of the day where we sat as a couple, without distractions.There used to be four of us with my grandparents.But I was often impatient and wanted to play.
It became significantly less.It must have changed sometime after my grandparents died.I often had to take care of my own food.Lydia was working or in the living room watching TV.

Links.Option: She didn't seem to want to take much care of me anymore.
She was often busy.It's not easy being a single mother.

Things.Name: shelf
Things.ExamineText: The opened shelf with beautiful ceramic dishes

Thought.Thought: A small, old kitchen cupboard.

NextNode.Thought: This is where Lydia stored her precious ceramic collection for special occasions.Even if she no longer made pottery herself.She maintained her passion for ceramics.I wasn't allowed to go there.

Links.Option: I don't need anything from the closet.
Maybe there's a watering can or something like that in here.[Open]
There are lots of stacked plates, a few ceramic cups and other dishes hidden behind them.

NextNode.Thought: It's very nice dishes.I have direct respect for it and fear of breaking something.The plates are from my grandparents and my mother bought the cups.
Let's see.I carefully pull it out.It's a clay pot.She looks familiar to me.
It was shattered.I remember.I accidentally broke it when it was on the dining room table and I bumped into it.I was maybe 12 years old then.
She pushed me to the floor and screamed: Clean this up!
No wonder dad ran away.If I had known that, I would have done the same.I can tell you that.So her words echo in me.

Links.Option: Then I cut myself on the glass.

NextNode.Thought: I screamed.Not because of the pain from the cut.It was a cry for help but also a cry of desperation, desperate to be me, a burden, bringing nothing good into the world, only suffering for my mother.The desperation to exist.

Links.Option: Lydia has neatly glued the jug back together.

NextNode.Thought: But she left me screaming.With guilt, shame and desperate fear of rejection

Links.Option: I feel like a monster.Still.It's her fault.
I don't want to think about it any further.
What's that hidden thing in the back corner?

Things.Name: Shards
Things.ExamineText: The shards of my mother's beloved teapot.

Thought.Thought: What's left of the pot.

NextNode.Thought: I was still a small child.She was a grown woman.She had restored the teapot, repaired it, put its individual parts together to form a whole.

Links.Option: She had broken me further and further over the years.

NextNode.Thought: Now the pieces are too small to put back together.
To be this guilt, this burden in their lives, to be the reason my father abandoned me and my mother when I was about six months old, to be the reason for all the evil in the world?

Links.Option: How can I help it that she gave birth to me?
What had I done to her to deserve this?

Thought.Thought: It's cold and damp here.It's dark.You can hardly see anything.

Things.Name: Door to storage room
Things.ExamineText: The door to the storage room

NextNode.Thought: How could I not know about this basement?

Links.Option: It's not particularly comfortable, but I'll stay here for a while.

Things.Name: mattress
Things.ExamineText: A mattress

Things.Name: Hole in wall
Things.ExamineText: A hole in the wall.There are pieces of paper and a pen inside.

Thought.Thought: A cavity in the wall.[Investigate]

NextNode.Thought: I can see a small stack of curled paper, a small pocket knife and a short pencil.
Many of the pages are already faded.The letters are no longer recognizable.But one page in the middle of the stack has been relatively well preserved.The author appears to have been imprisoned here.
These pages were the only thing that allowed the author to persevere.He always has a note in his pocket in case he gets locked up again.

To protect him from the influences of the outside world, his mother said, just as she did when the bombers came in World War II.He had been good and would always listen to every word.It is written in a childlike way, with simple words.Then part of it is illegible.Again and again, letters are blurry and disappear into small craters.It's like drops of water have fallen onto the paper.
Perhaps.Then there is a date "04/11/1965" followed by two letters "L T".
Her mother, my grandmother, must have locked her down here when she was a child.That's why I was never allowed into the basement.That's why she kept this room from me and hid it.

Links.Option: She was afraid of this room.Or from becoming like her mother and locking me up.
Why did the mother do that?
I get the eight or so pages of paper out of the tray.

EventThought.Thought: Why didn't you ever tell me about it?

NextNode.Thought: My mother is also nothing more than a child.She lived with this trauma all these years, she never told me about it.
The teapot was my grandmother's pot.Maybe she was angry when I broke the ceramic pot, not out of frustration and hatred of me, but out of fear and hatred of her mother.
She didn't even make it out of her parents' house.
I miss my mother.I wish she was still alive.What should I do?I don't know how to continue.I don't know what to feel.I don't know what to think.I don't even know what I am.

Maybe Lydia damaged a lot of things in me.But Lydia from 1965 made it clear to me that it doesn't help to stay in this time.I am no longer the seven-year-old girl who is slowly threatening to disappear.

I have to decide for myself what I am.It won't be easy.But it is the only way out of this suffering.This is all I have left and all I need.I take the notes with me from the basement to the surface of the house.It's time to start clearing out.I still have a lot to do.

Links.Option: I'm excited to see what else I find.
I am not a monster, not invisible, not a child anymore.

NextNode.Thought: I have to finish it.
I deserve nothing more than to be ripped apart.
I'm slowly disappearing.
I'm just a kid who can't take care of himself.

Links.Option: I'm laying down here like my mother did.
She was a child who tried to raise a child with her means without having to lock him in a basement.
She could never become independent.She had me too early for that.
And she never bad-mouthed my grandma either.

Things.Name: Lydia's bed
Things.ExamineText: This is Lydia's bed

Thought.Thought: As a small child, I often jumped into bed with Lydia during thunderstorms.

NextNode.Thought: I snuggled up to my mother.Sometimes she reciprocated.

Links.Option: At least I always felt safe.
If she didn't reciprocate it was worse than the nightmare or the storm I was running from.

NextNode.Thought: Every time I came in I was afraid she wouldn't move and would just be dead. I lay in bed with her and listened to her heartbeat to make sure she was still alive.
I wanted to take all the burden off her.I held her close and felt like I could take the bad energy out of her, making me feel worse and her better.

Links.Option: Then there were the pictures I painted for her.
But even though her body was functioning, there was no emotion.
When she was feeling bad, she lay here almost motionless.

Things.Name: Image of a flower
Things.ExamineText: This is a picture of a flower.

Thought.Thought: This is a picture of a flower.

NextNode.Thought: The yellow watercolor paint comes into its own very well!

Links.Option: I drew this.[Take a closer look]

NextNode.Thought: There must be countless of these flower pictures.I remember how after a while my mother said in a frail voice that I should paint her one of my beautiful flower pictures.Then she would definitely feel better again.
She was always happy about it.They were the few times I felt useful.And soon after we were in the garden together and we were both feeling better.

Links.Option: I later noticed that she often took some kind of medication to quickly feel better.

NextNode.Thought: Sometimes she gave me some too.Nevertheless, I had the feeling that I was helping her with painting and taking some of the bad mood off her.Now I think she sent me to paint and take her pick-me-up in the meantime.It must have been hard for her to pull herself together every time.
I should at least water the plants in the apartment.Lydia would definitely be happy about that.Maybe there's a watering can in the kitchen or something.

Links.Option: But I couldn't help her depressive phases.And yet I felt, and she made me feel, that it was up to me to get her out of there.
I remember often painting pictures of flowers.

Links.Option: My room looks almost exactly the same as before.

If Lydia has saved everything possible, there might even be an address book with her name in it.It must have been a long time ago, so it must have been at the beginning.

In fact, everything is still in here.Even my school folders are still on the shelf.It's like Lydia hasn't touched anything here since I moved out.
Old math folders with tests and exercise sheets.German homework.A big folder with drawings or something.
The typical drawings of simple houses and a sun or clouds.I must have been very young when I drew this.And then there is this tangle of lines.Something can be seen behind it.

I remember painting the lines.I was sad and angry at the same time.I drew myself lying in bed crying.And then painted lots of lines over it, like a veil, so that I disappear.I wanted to be gone.I wanted to become invisible.I still have that feeling often.

Everything I did at school used to be on this bookshelf.[Investigate]
I'm not interested right now.That's all long gone.

Thought.Thought: I like the hallway downstairs better.It's so bare here.

Things.Name: Door to the stairs upstairs
Things.ExamineText: The door to the stairs upstairs

Thought.Thought: The door to the stairs.

NextNode.Thought: Here you go back to the stairs to get to the ground floor.

Things.Name: Door to the bedroom
Things.ExamineText: The door to the bedroom

Thought.Thought: Lydia's bedroom should be here.

NextNode.Thought: Maybe I'll find something interesting here.

Things.Name: Door to the children's room
Things.ExamineText: The door to the children's room

Thought.Thought: My old childhood room.

NextNode.Thought: Now it's probably more of a guest room.

Links.Option: I don't feel like dealing with my childhood traumas right now.

Things.Name: Door to the balcony
Things.ExamineText: The door to the balcony

Thought.Thought: This is the stairwell.Here the floors and the storage room are connected to each other.

Things.Name: Door to storage room
Things.ExamineText: The door to the storage room

Thought.Thought: This is the storage room.

NextNode.Thought: There's a lot to do in there.

Things.Name: Door to the ground floor hallway
Things.ExamineText: The door to the hallway on the ground floor

Thought.Thought: The door to the hallway.

NextNode.Thought: It's a shame that all the plants there are already half dead.

Things.Name: Stairs to the upper floor
Things.ExamineText: The stairs to the upper floor

Thought.Thought: The spiral staircase to the first floor.

NextNode.Thought: I've always really liked the curved shape.

Things.Name: Stairs to the ground floor
Things.ExamineText: The stairs to the ground floor

Thought.Thought: Here you go back down to the ground floor

NextNode.Thought: Do we want to go back down?

Things.Name: Door to the old living room
Things.ExamineText: The door to the old living room

Thought.Thought: This is the old living room, at least that's how it was when I lived up here with my mother as a child.At that time my grandparents lived on the ground floor.The door is locked.

Things.Name: Door to the upstairs hallway
Things.ExamineText: The door to the first floor hallway

Thought.Thought: The door to the hallway.

NextNode.Thought: The hallway leads to the balcony, Lydia's bedroom and my former children's room.

Thought.Thought: There's always been so much stuff lying around here.

NextNode.Thought: Cardboard boxes are stacked up to the top like a wall.Lydia only ever had to go to the first couple for cleaning and gardening.

Links.Option: Half the house is a storage room.

Things.Name: Cellar door
Things.ExamineText: This is the door to the basement.

Thought.Thought: A huge steel door.

NextNode.Thought: It was probably deliberately hidden under all the boxes.

Links.Option: Why didn't I know about this?

NextNode.Thought: I think I remember it now.When I was very small and my grandparents lived here, the door was still there.But shortly after my grandparents died, she put boxes of my grandparents' old stuff here and blocked the door.Maybe it was even the first thing she did.

Links.Option: I think she was afraid of that basement.

NextNode.Thought: This must have already been installed in the original building of the house.Probably a cellar that could also be used as a bunker.

Links.Option: Let's take a look around there.[Open]
Of course I dare to go down into the dark old cellar that my mother was probably afraid of.But I don't feel like it right now.
What kind of door is that?

Things.Name: Cardboard boxes with decoration stuff
Things.ExamineText: That's a lot of boxes.

Thought.Thought: There's a lot of decoration in here.Christmas decorations, Easter decorations, decorations.But the box is already pretty dusty.It had probably been a long time since my mother had been festive.

NextNode.Thought: Quite a lot of odds and ends...

Links.Option: This will be fun to put away.This is something for the future-Marla.
The throbbing comes from this direction.I have to move the boxes away.[Move]

Things.Name: Cardboard boxes with old dishes
Things.ExamineText: There are more boxes.

Thought.Thought: Old dishes, some documents, folders, decorative figures.Just a lot more stuff.It'll be fun to get rid of everything.

Things.Name: A few smaller boxes
Things.ExamineText: Even more smaller boxes

Things.ExamineText: A broom

Things.ExamineText: A shelf

Things.ExamineText: A mop

Things.ExamineText: A bucket

Things.ExamineText: The door to the stairs

Thought.Thought: The door to the stairwell.

NextNode.Thought: Do I need anything else here?

Thought.Thought: What is that strange throbbing?It's gotten louder.

NextNode.Thought: Sounds strange.

Links.Option: Maybe we can find the source of the throbbing.

Things.Name: Upper floor
Things.ExamineText: Stairs to the upper floor

Thought.Thought: Here you go to the stairs to the upper floor.

NextNode.Thought: My room was upstairs.I often walked through there after school.

Things.ExamineText: The door to the living room

Things.ExamineText: The stairs to the upper floor

Thought.Thought: The spiral staircase to the first floor.

NextNode.Thought: I've always really liked the curved shape.

Things.Name: Dream: Door to the ground floor hallway
Things.ExamineText: The door to the hallway on the ground floor

Things.Name: Door to the hallway?
Things.ExamineText: The door to the first floor hallway, oh no.It leads to the children's room.

Thought.Thought: That should be the door to the hallway.

NextNode.Thought: The hallway leads to the balcony, Lydia's bedroom and my former children's room.

Commands.ThoughtText: That was a really strange dream.I'm still shaking.I just want to go back to sleep.But I have to get up now.Maybe a shower or something will help me.

Thought.Thought: This isn't the hallway.This is my old room.What is that weird thing there?

Things.Name: Door to the upstairs hallway
Things.ExamineText: The door to the upstairs hallway?

Thought.Thought: Where am I?Why is it so dark?

NextNode.Thought: Did I sleep?I can turn on the flashlight with the f key.

Links.Option: Let's take a look around.[Stand up]

Thought.Thought: The path to the hallway

NextNode.Thought: Get back to work?

Links.Option: I'd rather keep looking around here.

Things.ExamineText: A comfortable sofa
